title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section follows. The "Family Act of 2011" is recognized as the short title for this Act. Congress acknowledges infertility as a disease and a public health concern, with approximately 3,000,000 affected individuals. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 States mandating comprehensive coverage, excluding most employer-sponsored plans. In vitro fertilization is covered by 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans. Out-of-pocket expenses for in vitro fertilization are significant, with coverage by only 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans, even in States with coverage mandates. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section providing a credit for certain infertility treatments. The new section provides a tax credit of 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per eligible individual. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is subject to reduction based on adjusted gross income without considering certain sections, and no double benefit is allowed if a deduction or credit is taken under another provision of the tax code. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is limited if reimbursement is received from a federal, state, or local program, or from an insurance policy. The credit amount allowed is also subject to a limitation based on the amount of tax for the taxable year. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is limited based on the amount of tax for the taxable year. The credit allowed shall not exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27. Unused credit can be carried forward in certain cases. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed for the current year. No credit can be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after it arose. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year, up to the 5th year after it arose. Qualified infertility treatment expenses include in vitro fertilization administered by a licensed medical practitioner for diagnosed infertility. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward for up to 5 years. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical procedures that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. The term 'infertility' refers to the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, excluding infertility caused by procedures designed for sterilization. An eligible individual is diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the US. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward for up to 5 years, including fertility preservation procedures before medical treatments that may cause infertility. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward for up to 5 years. Married taxpayers must file joint returns. Dollar limitations will be adjusted for inflation starting in 2012. The income limitation for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment based on the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The taxable year begins with a cost-of-living adjustment based on the calendar year. Amounts not multiples of $10 will be rounded. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. "Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to sections 23A, 25D, 27, and 1400C for infertility treatments. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011."
